docs.lead_paragraph: Early this year Congress and the White House entertained dreams of passing all kinds of health care legislation. President Bush and Senator Edward Kennedy were supposedly working on a patients' ''bill of rights.'' There was even talk of enacting a prescription drug benefit for the elderly. But such talk has vanished. Instead a sober recognition has settled in Washington that little can be done to expand or improve health coverage while health care costs spiral out of control and the federal budget sinks deeper into deficit. Lawmakers seem to be betting that voters will not punish them for inaction. But they cannot put off the issue forever. A decade ago, when the cost of health care was also soaring, many experts were sure they had a solution -- managed care and competition. A revolution in health care delivery took place, and costs indeed seemed under control. But in the last couple of years they have gone back to rising at double-digit rates. Even the experts are shaken, because there is no magic solution this time around. Health maintenance organizations and insurance companies are not high on anyone's list of favorite enterprises. But in the current environment, lawmakers seem loath to add new requirements like a patient's right to sue, or parity between regular health care and mental health benefits, because of the cost.
docs.abstract: Editorial says sober recognition has settled in Washington that little can be done to expand or improve health coverage while health care costs spiral out of control and federal budget sinks deeper into deficit; says lawmakers seem to think voters will not punish them for inaction, but sooner or later demand for health care will be high on agenda again, and this could happen before election in Nov

docs.lead_paragraph: I slowed down as I approached a fork in the highway, unsure of which arm to take. The driver behind me was on my tail, so impatient that he tried to pass me on the right just as I headed for the right fork, forcing him to slam on his brakes. He became so infuriated that he pulled right in front of my car and each time I moved he repeatedly slammed on his brakes, forcing me to brake suddenly again and again, endangering not only me but himself and the driver behind me.

headline.main: Why Angry People Can't Control the Short Fuse

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on hostility and anger and link to early heart attacks and stroke; describes how to recognize hostility, what triggers anger and how to calm down; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF art in the broadest sense peers into the mysteries of life, then an art dedicated to the structure of life itself is of momentous relevance. That imposing premise informs ''Gene(sis): Contemporary Art Explores Human Genomics,'' an exhibition that opened in April at the University of Washington's Henry Art Gallery in Seattle. At once clever and awkward, the show's title evokes the biblical loftiness of Divine Origin and an altogether cooler scrutiny of the scientific, ethical and legal issues pulsing from the very nucleus of our genetic being.

headline.main: Art/Architecture; The Wonders Of Genetics Breed A New Art

docs.abstract: Article on Gene(sis): Contemporary Art Explores Human Genomics, traveling show currently at University of Washington in Seattle; focuses on ways in which contemporary artists are considering and illustrating issues of genetics, genetic manipulation and ethics; photos (M)
